description: Borrowed from Latin stet (“let it stand”).

entries.meaning: A symbol used by proofreaders and typesetters to indicate that a word or phrase that was crossed out should still remain.
examples: And my copyeditors at HarperCollins want me to use the word “commodified” exclusively, since it’s the only one in Websters. But I see the words as very different, and have issued a big STET on that one.

verbs.description: stet (third-person singular simple present stets, present participle stetting, simple past and past participle stetted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To let (edited material) stand, or remain as it was.
